value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">33</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">In every 
          <choice>
            <sic>Elizabethna</sic>
            <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
          </choice> play sunk beyond recall.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">If xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxm</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">somxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The <del hand="typewriter">life</del> The reader then is born sometime in</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the 
          <choice>
            <sic>siteenth</sic>
            <corr>sixteenth</corr>
          </choice> century. But he is xmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxm</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">but his 
          <choice>
            <sic>p wer</sic>
            <corr>power</corr>
          </choice> of influencing the playwright is very weak</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in the early days. The 
          <choice>
            <sic>twentiteh</sic>
            <corr>twentieth</corr>
          </choice> century reader</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that is to say, 
          <choice>
            <sic>instinctivly</sic>
            <corr>instinctively</corr>
          </choice> tries to adapt himself</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to unfamiliar conditions in reading the earlier plays.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He tries to supply the trumpets and the flags; the citizens</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the apprentices. He 
          <choice>
            <sic>substanitates</sic>
            <corr>substantiates</corr>
          </choice> the <del hand="ms">rather</del> shadowy</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">emotion that is all he can get in the plays with a dip into</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-phen" key="Henslowe, Philip">
          <choice>
            <sic>Hensloew</sic>
            <corr>Henslowe</corr>
          </choice></rs>, with a dip into <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rhol" key="Holinshed, Raphael">
            <choice>
              <sic>Holingshed</sic>
              <corr>Holinshed</corr>
            </choice></rs>. He labours to supply</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the sunk parts of the play;  <del hand="ms">he labours</del> to revive</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the vanished cooperation between the playwright and the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">audience. And he is perpetually rebuffed. He cannot</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">read the play into 
          <choice>
            <sic>comlete</sic>
            <corr>complete</corr>
          </choice> being. He is therefore apt</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to become not a reader but a student, a careful</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">collector of scattered bones. Reading is an imperfect</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">way of bringing the early plays into existence. It is only</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">fitfully that the readers faculty comes into play.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">When the dramatist becomes 
          <choice>
            <sic>consc ous</sic>
            <corr>conscious</corr>
          </choice> of the play as a work</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of art; when he is able to unite the play by something</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in himself-- his 
          <choice>
            <sic>personal ty</sic>
            <corr>personality</corr>
          </choice>, his style, his conception</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it is then that he brings the reader into existence.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The life history of the reader from Elizabethan</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">times to our own is full of obscurity. At some point his</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">ear must have been much more acute than it is now; his sight</l>
